description:
Kwoniella newhampshirensis is a species of yeast that was first isolated from soil samples collected in New Hampshire, United States. It belongs to the genus Kwoniella, which is a group of basidiomycetous yeasts.

The cells of Kwoniella newhampshirensis are typically round to oval in shape, and they reproduce asexually through budding. The species is able to ferment a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, sucrose, and maltose, as part of its metabolism.

Phylogenetic analysis based on the nucleotide sequences of the D1/D2 domain of the large subunit (26S) rRNA gene has shown that Kwoniella newhampshirensis is closely related to other species within the Kwoniella genus, which are found in diverse environments such as soil, water, and the gastrointestinal tracts of animals.

Further studies on the ecology, physiology, and potential applications of Kwoniella newhampshirensis may provide insights into the role of this yeast species in its natural habitat and its potential use in biotechnological processes.
